Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/10/22. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan and an A rated fire inspection, a
regular license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation of
an admission physical examination for each resident,
unless an earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year prior
to admission or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after admission.
2 of 3 youth files reviewed did not have an admission physical.
R 400.4552 Heating devices and flame-producing devices.
(8) All furnaces shall be inspected on an annual basis by a
licensed inspector. A copy of the inspection must be made
available to the qualified fire inspector or the department's
licensing authority upon request.
Furnaces and water heaters were not inspected as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:

1) Psychological Services

Psychological services are defined as various professional
activities or methods, provided by a licensed Master Social
Worker, licensed Professional Counselor, licensed
psychologist, or a limited licensed psychologist, including
therapy with youth individually or in groups, consultation
with staff, administering and interpreting psychological
consultation with staff, administering and interpreting
psychological tests and work with families.
During interviews both youth and staff indicated a need for therapy services and
therapy groups that are run by qualified individuals. The Chief Administrator
indicated they have been without a therapist for 8 months. The position has been
posted but they have not had any qualified applicants. He reported they were unable
to work with contractors due to insurance issues.

 Physicals are Well Child Exams and should be completed by a doctor, nurse

V. CONSULTATION

 Strategies for obtaining new staff.
 Find a contractor to provide therapy while searching for a candidate to hire.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
Special Investigation 2021C0214025 was initiated when it was reported a staff
member put his knee on a youths back while in a restraint. The facility was found in
violation of R 400.4159 Resident restraint for not using proper restraint technique,
JRM 610 Youth Restraint due to the facility’s policy not matching the JRM policy, and
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; and staff qualifications
because the staff involved was substantiated for physical abuse. A CAP was
accepted on 11/10/21. The staff member was terminated, and all CAP components
have been completed.
There were not any incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The facility has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
Special Investigation 2021C0103033 was initiated when it was reported a youth was
restrained for property destruction. No violations were found regarding the allegations
however additional findings were found. The facility was found in violation of R
400.4159 Resident restraint because staff escalated the youth then restrained him in
an unsafe location and prone position. A CAP was accepted on 10/29/21. All CAP
components have been completed.
Special Investigation 2022C0214009 alleged a staff argued with a youth, grabbed the
youth’s wrist and pushed the youth. No violations for the allegations were found,
however, there was an additional finding. The facility was cited for a contract violation
due to not reporting incidents in MiSACWIS. A CAP was accepted on 1/20/22. All
CAP components have been completed.
Special Investigation 2022C0103008 was initiated when it was reported staff
conducted a restraint when a restraint was not warranted. The facility was found in
violation of R 400.159 Resident restraint due to an unwarranted and unsafe restraint.
A CAP was accepted on 4/8/22. CAP components are in place and continue to be
monitored.
6

Chief Administrator Report
The Chief Administrator indicated that the previous year’s CAP has been working and
this is evidenced by not having any repeat violations this year. They continue to work
on getting staff to complete trainings and reducing restraints. The facility had 14
unplanned discharges during this review period. 11 of those discharges were issued
removal requests due to meeting the maximum benefit of the program. The other
unplanned discharges were due to AWOLs and court terminating the youths’ stays.
Interviews
The supervisor interviewed indicated a need for therapy services for the youth and
the need for qualified individuals to lead therapy groups in order for youth to benefit
from the program. Two youth indicated they felt a need for therapy services. This
information was communicated to the Chief Administrator. The Chief Administrator
indicated they are having trouble finding a qualified candidate and the youths
insurance was not going to pay for a contractor to supply therapy services.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan and an A rated fire inspection, it is recommended
that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
